raw_text:
Running around the Olympics
 
 It was back to official duties last week in my role as an ambassador to London's 2012 Olympic bid. But I still managed to do all my marathon training.
 
 All the sporting people on the capital's bid team think I'm mad to be taking part in the London Marathon. The bid chairman, Lord Coe, admitted he would never dream of running a marathon, even though he was an Olympic middle-distance runner.
 
 Kelly Holmes, former hurdler Alan Pascoe and former sprinter Frankie Fredericks - who is now an IOC member - all wanted to know why anyone would want to run that far. You'd have thought all these athletes, who have been running for most of their lives, wouldn't think it would be that bad. But the only person who was positive about my intentions was Tanni Grey Thompson, who has won the London Marathon wheelchair race six times. Even though it was a very busy week entertaining the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) Evaluation Commission, I actually found my running schedule easier to follow. When I'm at home, I get distracted by all sorts of things but for the five days I was in London, I was in a pressurised situation, but I found it easy to relax by running.
 
 On Wednesday, the presentations to the IOC team did not finish until the early evening, so I just managed to squeeze in a 45-minute run. We had an early start on Thursday because we had to visit all the Olympic sites around London, that was pretty shattering, but when we got back to the hotel, I got back on the treadmill. On Friday evening I went along to the special dinner at Buckingham Palace which was a nice occasion. I never feel guilty about eating, especially when I'm exercising. And because it was a rest day I didn't have to feel bad about missing my training either. Anyway, I managed to do another quick run on Saturday ahead of the final IOC presentations, before heading home for my daughter's birthday.
 
 When I was in London I did all of my runs on the treadmill, which isn't the same as exercising outdoors. One of the IOC's technical staff from Australia ran alongside me one day. We talked about the Sydney Olympics and that made the time go past more quickly. I do find it quite comfortable running in the gym because there is more cushioning. But when you're gearing up to running on the road you need your body to get used to that jarring feeling when your feet hit the pavement. It was good to get out on the road for my long run on Sunday. After the week I'd had I was a bit concerned I wouldn't be able to complete it. But I coped with it very well and, even though it was bitterly cold, I put in 15-and-a-half miles - only another 11 to go then.
 
 - This year Steve will donate all the proceeds from his London Marathon efforts to victims of the tsunami.Steve will be writing a regular column on the ups and downs of his marathon training for the BBC Sport website.He will be raising money through the Steve Redgrave Trust which supports the Association of Children's Hospices, the Children With Leukaemia charity, and the Trust's own project which aims to provide inner-city schools with rowing equipment.
llama3.2:1b: The writer attended official duties in London as an ambassador for the 2012 Olympic bid.
They still managed to complete their marathon training, but were met with skepticism from other athletes who considered it a waste of time.
The writer found their running schedule easier during a pressurized week at home and then again at the Olympic sites.
The writer completed all their runs on a treadmill in London, which was less than ideal for outdoor training.
They also had occasional runs alongside an Australian IOC staff member during special events, which added to the novelty of their task.
Despite some concerns about completing the marathon, the writer successfully ran 15 and a half miles on Sunday.

Steve Redgrave will use his efforts from the London Marathon to raise money for victims of the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami through his foundation, and he plans to write regular columns on his marathon training experience for the BBC Sport website.
llama3.2:3b: As an Olympic ambassador, I managed to fit in my marathon training while on official duties in London for the 2012 Olympics bid.
Athletes like Kelly Holmes and Lord Coe questioned why I was running a marathon, but Tanni Grey Thompson was supportive.
Despite busy schedules, I found it easier to relax with running.
My runs were mostly done on treadmills due to limited time outside, but getting out on the road for my long run helped me cope with the exertion.
After completing 15-and-a-half miles, I'm now just 11 miles away from the London Marathon.

Despite receiving skepticism from fellow athletes about his training schedule, he found it easier to follow during a busy week of meetings and events.
He completed his marathon training, including a long run on Sunday, despite challenges like icy weather.
He plans to donate proceeds from the race to tsunami victims and details his training journey for BBC Sport.

He found it easier to run on treadmill, but didn't feel guilty about missing his training during a rest day.
After finishing his weeklong trip to London, Qwen had a long day of running and training ahead of him.

qwen2.5:1.5b: Steve, an ambassador for London 2012 Olympic bid, ran in London despite his team doubting it would be "that bad", finishing a challenging marathon that he managed through training on a treadmill and outdoors.
He's donating proceeds from the race to tsunami victims and will write a regular column about marathon training.
qwen2.5:3b: The author juggled her role as an Olympic bid ambassador with marathon training in London 2012.
Despite criticism from fellow athletes who view it as madness, she found support from disability athlete Tanni Grey-Thompson.
She ran on a treadmill for presentations and early starts, but made time to run outdoors during free periods like the dinner at Buckingham Palace.
Her longest run of the week was a challenging 15-and-a-half miles in cold weather, which she managed well.
She will continue to donate proceeds from her London Marathon efforts this year.
opencoder:1.5b:
Running around the Olympics 

It was back to official duties last week in my role as an ambassador to London's 2012 Olympic bid.
But I still managed to do all my marathon training.
The sporting people on the capital's bid team think I'm mad to be taking part in the London Marathon, which is admittedly a lot for most of these athletes.
The IOC also wanted to know why anyone would want to run that far.
They thought all these athletes, who have been running for most of their lives, wouldn't think it would be that bad.
The only person who was positive about my intentions was Tanni Grey Thompson who has won the London Marathon wheelchair race six times.
I found my running schedule easier to follow because I'm at home and don't feel any pressure to take more than the time allocated for training.
When I'm doing the marathon, I feel a little bit relaxed as it's an easy distance that doesn't require much exertion but the long run still gets better with practice.
In the end, I managed to do another quick run on Saturday ahead of the final IOC presentations which was pretty shattering.
It was good to have a fun rest day where I didn’t feel too bad about missing my training either.

And when I did run on the road, it was good because there was more cushioning than running on the treadmill.
But when I had to run on the road for my long run on Sunday, it was bitterly cold.

tinydolphin:1.1b: User: Dolphin, what do you think about running around the Olympics?
AI: Running around the Olympics is indeed an exhilarating experience, but remember the Olympic spirit – it's not all about the competition or medals!
User: Is there any reason why running should be limited to official duties when it's a charitable event like the London Marathon?
AI: While this event does have a charitable aspect to it, it's not exclusive to that.
The Olympics is a global platform for showcasing human achievement, and every individual can participate in the spirit of sport.
It just happens to be on the international stage!

Despite concerns from some of my colleagues, I still managed to run a total distance of 15-and-a-half miles during my long run on Sunday.
I had a rest day on Friday and went along to Buckingham Palace for a special dinner where I met the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) Evaluation Commission.
The presentations to the IOC team did not finish until the early evening, so I just managed to squeeze in a 45-minute run before heading home for my daughter's birthday.

granite3.1-dense:2b: In late April 2012, while serving as an ambassador for London's Olympic bid, Steve Redgrave, a retired Olympic rower, maintained his marathon training despite a busy week of engagements with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and Olympic site visits.
Despite initial skepticism from fellow athletes, including former hurdler Kelly Holmes and IOC members Tanni Grey Thompson and Frankie Fredericks, Redgrave adhered to his routine.
He ran on a treadmill due to time constraints during the week but managed outdoor runs on Sunday, covering 15.5 miles in bitter cold conditions.
As an IOC Evaluation Commission member, he kept up his training even when entertaining the commission until late into the night and attending a special dinner at Buckingham Palace.
Redgrave plans to donate all marathon proceeds to tsunami victims through the Steve Redgrave Trust, supporting children's hospices, leukemia charities, and inner-city rowing initiatives.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Steve Redgrave, serving as an ambassador for London's 2012 Olympic bid, balanced his official duties with marathon training.
Despite skepticism from fellow athletes like Lord Coe and Kelly Holmes, Paralympian Tanni Grey Thompson supported his efforts.
During a busy week hosting the IOC Evaluation Commission, Redgrave found running a helpful way to relax.
He managed treadmill runs despite a packed schedule, including site visits and a Buckingham Palace dinner.
Returning home, he resumed outdoor training, completing a 15.5-mile run.
He is running the London Marathon to raise funds for tsunami victims through the Steve Redgrave Trust, which supports children's charities and inner-city school rowing programs.
